passages.text: Earnings Review: Nudge up FY25 NI guidance to RMB1.2bn; Balanced channel/category growth at improved cost efficiency; Neutral
1318.HK 12m Price Target: HK\\$89.00 Price: HK\\$94.05 Downside: \(5.4\%\)
We attended Mao Geping's results briefing on Aug 28 post its 1H25 results (see our First Take). Key takeaways include:

1) Reiterate FY25 sales guidance with better NI outlook at RMB1.2bn, catching up with market expectation: For FY25, management remains confident in delivering \(30\%\) yoy sales growth to RMB5bn, while NI guidance was nudged up to RMB1.2bn (from RMB1.18bn), implying improving ROI thanks to brand investments. The implied 2H25 growth is broadly similar to 1H25.

2) Product pipeline and category progress: Color cosmetics: Mgmt sees substantial headroom across multiple lines with clear star-SKU ambitions with new SKU launch sequence from blush, lip to eye products; Skincare: New skincare line testing has shown early success; in 2H25, the range will expand to address more skin needs; Fragrance: Roadmap includes advanced iterations tailored to environment, makeup looks, and emotional moods, with profitability expected to improve in 2H25. LT sales mix target for fragrance at 5-10%, benchmarking Chanel/Dior.

3) Channel strategy and execution: Online: Strong inflow from younger consumers trading up from mass brands. Douyin/Tmall grew by \(44\% /31\%\) yoy in 1H25. Douyin will remain as the focus for the company while with emphasis on ROI and avoiding over-reliance on top KOLs. Mgmt also saw opportunities in JD and Dewu. Offline: Customer base skews to higher-end international brand users. Sales per store rose from RMB2.4mn to RMB2.9mn in 1H25, driven by \(30 - 35\%\) new customer mix and repurchase rate improvement from \(28.7\%\) to \(30.3\%\) . Store network target is 600 stores, with about 30 net openings per year.
4) Overseas: Dual-track expansion online and offline. The first store outside Mainland China is slated for Hong Kong Harbour City in
Market cap: HK\\$46.1bn / \(5.9bn Enterprise value: HK\) 42.2bn / \(5.4bn 3m ADTV: HK\) 292.2mn / \(37.3mn China/ Korea Cosmetics & Jewelry M&A Rank: 3 Leases incl. in net debt & EV: Yes

2H25, with subsequent rollout plans for Singapore, Japan, and South Korea.

GS view: Overall we think mgns tone is constructive and the guidance provides high visibility into earnings this year to top of an easier base into 2H. The balanced growth of color makeup vs. skincare, online vs. offline under improved ROI have showcased the brand's healthy momentum and operational efficiency. Yet, we note MGP remains the most expensive stock in the new consumption space, trading at 35x PE 2025E against a 30% 2024- 2025 NI CAGR, also largely pricing in our LT scenario of RMB10bn sales upside. Maintain Neutral.

Earnings revisions and TP: We revise up our 2025- 27E NI by \(2 - 3\%\) mainly to reflect improved profitability on enhanced ROI, partially offset by slightly weaker sales and GPM contraction. We now expect 2025 sales/NI of RMB5.1/1.2bn up \(32\% /36\%\) yoy respectively, or RMB1.21bn adj. NI if excluding RMB9mn ESOP expenses. Our TP now moves to HKD89 (vs. previous HKD86), implying 29x target 2025- 26 avg P/E against \(36\% /25\%\) 2025E/2026E NI growth yoy.

1. FY25 guidance: Mgmt reiterated target of 2023-26E \(30\%\) sales CAGR. For 2025, the company is confident to deliver \(30\%\) yoy sales growth, reaching RMB5bn. The company slightly revised up FY25 NI guidance to RMB1.2bn (vs. previously RMB1.18bn). Mgmt commented 2H is likely to deliver similar performance vs. 1H like last year and is confident to maintain a similar NI yoy growth as 1H25 at c. \(36\%\) into 2H.

- GPM: The 0.7ppt GPM contraction is mainly due to 1) Increased unit cost for color cosmetics with product iteration and upgrade; 2) Decreased GPM of makeup school business with more investment into teaching resources and the cancellation of certification fee for apprentice, which accounted for 0.25ppt contraction.

- Selling expenses ratio: The 2.4ppt contraction can be attributed to increase brand recognition from consumers and enhanced customer acquisition efficiency due to efforts in brand equity building, leading to lower selling expenses ratio in both offline and online channel.

- Color cosmetics: Currently foundation makeup/color makeup contributes to \(50\% /50\%\) of color cosmetics segment. Mgmt sees vast potential for different product lines and star SKUs. For new SKU launches, the company will begin by introducing blush products, followed by lip products, and then expand into eye products.

- Skincare: Mgmt highlighted the outperformance of Caviar Serum, in addition to the traditional star SKU Black Cream. The testing of new skincare product line has achieved initial success. In t2H25, the company will offer more product choices to a wider range of consumers with different skincare needs.
- Fragrance: Moving forward, the company's offerings will include advanced versions

of fragrances, providing products tailored to different environments, makeup styles, and personal emotions. Mgmt commented that in 1H25, the volume of our perfume sales was relatively modest, and its cost- to- output ratio remained balanced, with no losses incurred, while profitability will improve into 2H25. In LT, mgmt targets for \(5 - 10\%\) sales mix from fragrance benchmarking to Chanel/Dior.

Online: Younger consumers who are upgrading from mass- market brands contributed to a considerable part of online customers. By platform, Douyin sales grew by \(44\%\) in 1H25, with the company effectively controlling costs and emphasizing ROI. With a KOL livestreaming mix over \(50\%\) , the company is avoiding over- reliance on top KOLs while prefer to utilize mid- tier KOLs. The company will continue to put emphasis on Douyin due to its strong momentum despite slightly lower profitability. Tmall saw a \(33\%\) yoy growth in 1H25, and JD also experienced strong growth through distributors. Mgmt also saw opportunities in emerging platforms such as JD and Dewu going forward. While online growth remains strong, the company will not deliberately pursue an increased online sales proportion.

Offline: Offline customers are mainly higher- end international brand consumers with higher repurchase rate. In 1H25, sales per store increased from RMB2.4mn to RMB2.9m, driven by new customers ( \(30 - 35\%\) mix) and increased repurchase rate (improved from \(28.7\%\) to \(30.3\%\) ). The company targets for 600 offline stores with 30 net openings each year.

Overseas expansion: The company will expand into overseas market in both online and offline channel and will open its first store outside ML China in HK Harbour City in 2H25, with further expansion plan into Singapore, Japan, and South Korea in the future.
5. Double 11 strategy: Mgmt highlighted the success of strategy used in 618 shopping festival will replicate the successful 618 strategy for Double 11.
6. Dividend: Mgmt set \(30\%\) as a base for dividend payout ratio.

Earnings revision: We cut our 2025- 27E sales/GPM by \(0.3\% - 0.8\% /0.3 - 0.6\) ppt to reflect 1H25 results. We revise down 2025- 27E selling expenses ratio by 1.5- 1.8ppt to reflect improved operation efficiency. As such, we revise up our 2025- 27E NI by \(2 - 3\%\) . We now expect 2025E reported NI of Rmb1.2bn, up \(36\%\) yoy with \(32\%\) yoy sales growth or adjusted NI at Rmb1.21bn up \(31\%\) yoy.

TP: Our 12m TP moves to HKD89 (vs. previous HKD86), still based on a 25x 2027E P/E discounted back to mid- 2026E using an \(8.9\%\) COE, implying 29x target 2025- 26 avg PE against \(36\% /25\%\) 2025E/2026E NI growth yoy.

Key risks: 1) Faster/slower penetration of beauty consumption in China; 2) Faster/slower online penetration; 3) New star SKU development especially in skincare category; 4) Higher/lower ROI when expanding consumer base especially into higher tier and online; 5) Key person risk.
Exhibit 1: MGP earnings revision
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: Our 12m TP moves to HKD89, implying \(8\%\) downside

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FC and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. We have investment banking and other business relationships with a substantial percentage of the companies covered by Global Investment Research. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

The analysts named in this report may have from time to time discussed with our clients, including Goldman Sachs salespersons and traders, or may discuss in this report, trading strategies that reference catalysts or events that may have a near- term impact on the market price of the equity securities discussed in this report, which impact may be directionally counter to the analyst's published price target expectations for such stocks. Any such trading strategies are distinct from and do not affect the analyst's fundamental equity rating for such stocks, which rating reflects a stock's return potential relative to its coverage universe as described herein.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fom_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offering(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
